Name: Pattern Recognition - PE
Text: We observe that the user works on specific documents: Quarterly_Report.docx in Microsoft Word, Document1.docx in Microsoft Word, Email - Inbox in Google Chrome for email, Report_Draft.pdf in Adobe Acrobat, Budget_2024.xlsx in Microsoft Excel.

Name: Inductive Reasoning - PE
Text: We can group by the window title and the application. But note: the same window title might reappear after switching away and coming back. We need to consider continuity.

Name: Abductive Reasoning - IND
Text: A case should represent a logical unit of work. In this context, we can consider each document/email as a case. However, note that the user switches between documents and applications.

Name: Hypothesis Generation - PE
Text: We can use the following logic for case grouping: Each time the user focuses on a window with a unique document/description and starts working on it, we can consider it as part of a case. But if the same document is worked on in two separate sessions with other activities in between on different documents, we might keep them together as one case for that document.

Name: Backtracking - NE
Text: Alternatively, we can break by application context? However, note that the user might be working on multiple tasks simultaneously interleaving.

Name: Hypothesis Generation - PE
Text: We can define a case by the unique combination of Application, Window. However, note that the same App, Window might be used for a long time with multiple saves, etc. and that is acceptable.

Name: Deductive Reasoning - PE
Text: For Microsoft Word: the window title which is the document name is the case ID. For Google Chrome: we have the window title Email - Inbox, but we also see an action that opens a specific email. We can use the email subject as the case ID. For Adobe Acrobat: window title is Report_Draft.pdf, so case ID: Report_Draft.pdf. For Excel: Budget_2024.xlsx.

Name: Validation - IND
Text: The SWITCH event itself? It is from Word to Chrome. It does not belong to a specific case? We can assign it to the last active case? Or we can assign it to the case that is being switched to?

Name: Hypothesis Generation - PE
Text: We can treat the SWITCH events as system activities and assign them to the case that is being focused on next. The SWITCH event is a transition. We can assign the SWITCH event to the case that the user is switching to because it marks the start of work on that case.

Name: Backtracking - IND
Text: Option 1: Start the email case at the SWITCH event when the user switches to Chrome and then the CLICK event on the email is part of that case. Option 2: Start the email case at the CLICK event that opens the email.

Name: Heuristic Reasoning - PE
Text: Since the log only shows one email interaction, we can assign all events in Chrome from 09:02:00 until the switch at 09:04:00 to the email case. The SWITCH event at 09:01:45 is assigned to the email case.

Name: Inductive Reasoning - PE
Text: We can rename the SWITCH event to Open Application for the email case. And then the next events are the email interactions. This way, we capture the whole email session including the switch.

Name: Deductive Reasoning - PE
Text: Activity mapping: FOCUS: if it is the first event of the case: Open Document else: Resume Work. TYPING: Edit Content. SAVE: Save Document. SCROLL: Scroll Document. CLICK: based on action like Open Email, Reply to Email, Send Email. HIGHLIGHT: Highlight Text. CLOSE: Close Document. SWITCH: Open Application for the target case.

Name: Validation - PE
Text: We will create the event log step by step for this log: Event 0: FOCUS on Quarterly_Report.docx case_id = Quarterly_Report.docx activity = Open Document. Event 1: FOCUS on Document1.docx case_id=Document1.docx activity=Open Document.

Name: Heuristic Reasoning - PE
Text: Given the small size of the log, we can hardcode: For events with index in 5 to 10 which are from SWITCH to Send Email case_id = Email: Annual Meeting.
